div1.head: Study of Cases Reported by Colonial Authorities at Stann Creek, British Honduras, by [Emmett I. Vaughn], [1924]
div1.p: COPY
STUDY OF CASES REPORTED BY COLONIAL AUTHORITIES AT STANN CREEK, BRITISH HONDURAS

CASE NO. I - LUCIANO GAMBOA - This man's illness dates from November 3 but he
was not seen by Dr. C. S. Harwood, Assistant Medical Officer, until November 17
upon which date he also saw Case No. II - Nicasio Mena - for the first time.

Dr. Harwood had been called to Belize as a witness in a murder trial
the early part of November and did not return until the above date. Gamboa was
not admitted to the local hospital as he was convalescent when seen on the
seventeenth. Investigation shows that he returned to work at the lumber camp on
November 24.

Gamboa has spent his whole life in Stann Creek and has not visited, met
nor seen, to his knowledge, anyone from Mexico, Guatemala, Salvador or Honduras.
Before his illness he returned to Stann Creek from the lumber camp on Saturday,
October 25, and returned on Monday, October 27. The week previously he arrived
on Saturday, October 18 and returned on Monday, October 20.

Investigation fails to reveal an illness resembling his in houses near-
by or in his immediate neighborhood. At the camp his quarters were one-quarter
of a mile from those occupied by Nicasio Mena. If his case were yellow fever he
was infected between October 29 and November 1, during which time he was in the
lumber camp, and the female Aedes Aegypti biting him became infected between
October 17 and 20. November 3 to 6 represents the period in which he was in the
infective stage and a secondary case should have appeared in the period between
November 17 and 25. Careful investigation does not show a secondary case in
this period.

CASE NO. II - NICASIO MENA - This man's illness dates from Monday, November 10,
when he returned to the lumber camp where he was employed. As mentioned above
he was not seen by Dr. Harwood until November 17 when his condition was so grave
- 2 -
that he was admitted to the hospital. He was in Stann Creek for the week-end,
Saturday, October 25, to Monday, October 27, and from Saturday, November 1, to
Monday, November 3.

One year ago he returned to Stann Creek from Honduras where he had
spent five years. Since his return his only absences from Stann Creek have been
to Newtown on Commers Bight (7 miles away) and to the lumber camp - 19 miles
distant. His family states that he had neither seen nor visited anyone, to the
best of their knowledge, from Mexico, Guatemala, Salvador or Honduras. Investi-
gation did not reveal any illness resembling his in nearby or neighboring houses
at any recent period.

If his case were yellow fever he was infected in the period November 5
to 8 during which time he was working at the lumber camp, and the Aedes Aegypti
biting him probably became infected between October 24 and 27.

His infective stage is represented by the period November 10 to 13 and
a secondary case would probably have appeared between November 24 and December 2
and to date such case has not appeared.

There is no information to suggest that either Mena or Gamboa were
friends or ever visited each other. It is further noted that Mena and Gamboa
lived in widely separated parts of Stann Creek.

CASE NO. III - ADOLFO MENA - This child of nine years was not a relative or friend
of either of the above two cases; lived in a distant part of town and both mother
and child stated that they did not know Mena or Gamboa and had never seen them.

The first day of the child's illness was November 18 and the infection -
if any - took place between November 13 and 16 and the Aedes Aegypti should have
become infected in the period November 1 to 4. During these periods the child
was in Stann Creek and must have become infected in that place.

The infective stage of the child being November 18 to 21 a secondary
case could have been expected between December 2 and 10 but no such case has
appeared after the most careful investigation.

This child had never been outside of Stann Creek and the mother states
they know no one from Mexico, Guatemala, Salvador or Honduras.

GENERAL COMMENTS: It is obvious after scrutinizing the first dates of illness
(see charts attached) in each case that these cases are separate infections and
not a chain, or series, of cases from a single original infection. Seven days
elapsed between Gamboa's and Mena's first day of illness and eight days between
Mena and the child Mena. To have been a series beginning with Gamboa the first
day of Mena's illness should have been between November 17 and 25 and the child
Mena between November 24 and December 2.

The child Mena actually fell ill on November 18 and chronologically,
by a great stretch of imagination could have been considered a secondary case
from Gamboa but the history - both clinical and personal - renders this assumption
improbable - if not impossible.

It is obvious that an epidemiological connection between these three
cases is extremely improbable. A careful study of the clinical history of these
cases (to be discussed later) and an epidemiological study of them almost con-
vinces the writer that they were not yellow fever.

It must be borne in mind that Dr. Wilson, the Principal Medical Officer,
and Dr. Harwood, the Assistant Medical Officer, although having wide experience
in tropical diseases in the Far East were not familiar with yellow fever. Gamboa
was not seen until he was practically convalescent and the child Mena was probably
diagnosed as yellow fever as a measure of safety. To the writers mind only one
case of the three reported assumed aspects that were unusually suggestive of the
disease.

In order to trace these cases towards source of origin it is nec-
essary to approximate certain dates during which (if these cases were yellow
fever) the Aedes Aegypti biting them became infected. These approximate dates
are October 17 - 20; October 24 - 27, and November 1 - 4, and are based on the
assumption that the mosquito incubation period being twelve days and the female
Aedes feeding promptly at the end of this period. According to Bulletin 1354 -
Department of Agriculture - 1923 the female Aedes feeds 12 times in 31 days or
once in each two and one-half days - in other words at the end of the twelfth
day or beginning of the thirteenth she is ready to feed and this period cor-
responds with the completion of the incubation period.

A scrutiny of hospital records and interrogations in every direction
do not bring to light any case of illness in any manner resembling yellow fever
during the periods above mentioned.

It being impossible to establish an epidemiological chain in Stann
Creek attention was turned to the personnel of the Tidewater Lumber Company,
- 5 -
located 19 miles west of Stann Creek, where two of the cases were employed. On
December 29 a list of all the employees of the company with notes regarding cer-
tain employees was mailed to you. These notes referred to employees coming from
Mexico and Honduras. Of the employees noted only one has given a history that
merits further investigation:

ALMANAC RICKETTS - Mosquito Indian - aged 23 years and by occupation a
worker in mahogany camps. He had been employed in the mahogany camps on the Rio
Hondo, a river separating British Honduras from Mexican territory, and came to
Belize from Corazal about June 15 and on June 24 was admitted to the Belize Hos-
pital with a provisional diagnosis of Pernicious Anemia. He was discharged on
July 20 and his clinical history was not that of yellow fever. His temperature
chart from June 24 to July 5 is herewith attached.

His temperature from July 5 to 20 (date of discharge) is not furnished
as it was practically normal during that period. There is no record of his
whereabouts between this time and when he returned to Belize about October 15
when he “signed on” for work with the lumber company and came to Stann Creek dur-
ing the latter part of the month. On November 1 he was seen by Dr. Harwood and
stated that he had been ill for four days i.e. from October 28 with fever, ab-
dominal pain and vomiting. Mr. Mullins, his superintendent, informed me that he
saw Ricketts on the 30th and his sclerae were badly jaundiced. Ricketts shortly
afterwards returned to work and worked continuously until December 13 when the
camp closed down for the holiday season.
